Description: Despite recent attention being given to health equity in the United States and abroad, cancer disparities persist. The COVID-19 pandemic has taught us that there are important structural root causes of disparities agnostic to the type of threat to health and well-being.  The pandemic has laid bare the links between our fight against infection and non-communicable disease, the complexity and fragmentation of our health systems, and sadly, the inequities present amongst the most vulnerable.  A recent perspective in PLoS Medicine posits a role for implementation science in addressing the ‘wicked’ problems that have contributed to health inequities. In this session, we explore in detail (1) why applying a health equity lens to implementation science is crucial to achieve maximum impact on cancer control, (2) how taking a systems approach in designing implementation research can illuminate high leverage, cross-cutting implementation strategies, and (3) how rigor and reproducibility can be maintained using pragmatic designs.
